In fact, almost all Yunupingu's immediate problems stem from royalty money, and the way he shares it out: a tide of envy is directed at him, based on the presumption tha

he swims in cash. There is a degree, but only a small, pitiful degree of truth in this.

Each year, the bauxite mine and refinery at Gove, partly on Gumatj land, pays out a tiny slice of its revenue to the Northern Terr

Government in royalties, of which one third goes to the clans. The lion's share of this, 65 per cent, or just over $1.5 million in the last financial year, in turn goes to the Gumatj, and the Gumatj Association decides

it gets spent. Some $360,000 a year is guaranteed to the five main Gumatj families, perhaps 700 people, as their entitlement. Yunupingu, as the association's chair, draws a salary, $90,000, and has a special chairman's

to disburse, $100,000. These sums ensure that much of his life is spent dealing with demands from his poorer cousins for support. A good deal of the royalty money vanishes at once on vehicles for relatives; a quarter of

a million a year is spent on funeral ceremony costs. What remains is very little; it runs an office. The famous Gumatj helicopter, emblem of the lavish Yunupingu lifestyle, is in fact a revenue-raising asset, rented out

tourism and mining contractors. But this dribble of unearned income diverts the energies of the Gumatj, and other Yolngu groups, away from any hard engagement with the wage economy: by a bleak twist, the payments for th

mine the old Yolngu leaders fought to block have served to sap the will of the next generation. They have done much to leave Yunupingu, a beneficiary of this largesse, marooned - an antique leader in a world few younger

e strongly wish to occupy and own. The isolation is distinct: one feels it, and feels a man's, and a culture's, fate.

For Yunupingu, by now, in his battle for his traditions and their survival, has managed to make himse

into an icon of leadership, a symbol, as much as a living, breathing man. In his father's perfect image, he is the sheen of ancestry; he is power, and authority, and the essence of the clan. And, like many figures in ab

control over their people, he is on his own.

"I limit my private life," he says, "to my close family and friends: I tend not to give away my self, who I am, what I'm about; not even to my wives. There's very little of

that anyone really knows, and it worries me enormously that this core of my self goes unseen. Of course there's always a part of you that should be reserved, or you become vulnerable. And that's why I have never opened

completely, to anyone, about my life. I give so much of myself away, in public things, that I have to hold this core of me back, and have a secret self. And when I talk, sometimes, in my thoughts, I tune myself up, so h

I can't even hear myself speaking: and I wonder, then, who understands me - who could understand?"

Gradually, insistently, from such exchanges as this, over hours and days, one comes to see something of Yunupingu as he

y is, rather than as he might wish to be. One sees a leader whose life has been devoted to the task of driving ever onwards, towards his distant goals; a leader half-lost in his own receding dreams.

And perhaps it is be

of this context, and the immediacy of the social crisis confronting his world, that Yunupingu has turned abruptly, in the past year or so, to practical measures. The indigenous rights campaigner is now a ground-level ac

Early in February, Yunupingu threw himself into a fight to persuade the itinerant drinkers from his clan to leave their semi-permanent camps around the township of Nhulunbuy and return to their homelands. It was he who

t there with the drifters and town campers of his extended family, beneath the shadesails opposite the Woolworths carpark, urging and pleading with his kinsmen, while puzzled locals looked on. In September, in response t

an upsurge in petrol-sniffing by Yolngu children in Gove, Yunupingu rounded up as many as he could of those involved and transported them to Dhanaya for handson rehabilitation. These are scarcely the actions of a remove

high-handed monarch: for Yunupingu, every member of his clan and its many connected groups is his own flesh and blood.

This new engagement is matched by a deepening contempt for institutional Aboriginal politics, and a

t rejection of the Northern Territory's Government and land councils. Yunupingu has seen enough: he now believes traditional Aboriginal people must look after themselves; national institutions and indigenous leaders from

e non-traditional world have no more appeal to him. The model he prefers is autonomy and financial independence for the Yolngu realm. 

For 30 years he gave lip service to the dream of national and regional indigenous so

Today, he wants to see the Northern Land Council pushed aside. Instead, he believes there should be a Northern Territory "council of traditional leaders", a body he refers to in language as the "Delak", which would spea

for remote communities. Intriguingly, he would prefer it to have support funds from the private sector: it would negotiate directly over use of the Territory's vast tracts of Aboriginal-owned land, and it would grow to

over the powers of the existing northern region land council, and direct it.

This is a revolutionary blueprint - one that aims to take back power from the present indigenous elite, and from Territory politicians who cl

to speak for the Aboriginal world. "An urbanised contemporary leadership is not helping the situation of indigenous people in the bush," says Yunupingu. "It never has in the past; most of those leaders stole the show, t

over the national body, and left us with nothing."

Here we have the world-view of a man who has at last rejected everything about the status quo: the governmental structures, the policies, the results. Yunupingu is at

end of the line. He has decided family and culture come first, and last, and it is to them that he returns.

"I'm 60 years old," he says, "it's been a long road, and I'm thinking about our lives, and how they have to ch

We've come to the closing of a chapter in politics, and it hasn't worked. I aim from now on to commit myself to my immediate family: that's what I can do - that's all I can do. Teaching young men and women - stories for

, art for country, conservation for country."

A new kind of economic program flows logically from this. The multinational mining bauxite at Gove, Rio Tinto, wants to strike a new compact with the Yolngu people. Yunuping

wants to shift from royalty payments to equity: to own the assets of his land, and take the first share of profits from his country, not the last crumbs. In his vision, eventually the Gumatj will not be living on work-f

payments, drinking and despairing: they will be independent princes, land and investment-rich, players in their own right in the corporate world. It is a vision his brothers share, and its first glimmers are coming into

, with slow steps, on a cattle station set up on Gumatj land, where young Yunupingu family members have begun to work.

But a darker landscape still dominates, and these dreams, of course, are only words - words, nothing

, after four decades of struggling, and leading, and longing. Dusk, like a curtain, descends: the clan chief has new tasks to fulfil. Yunupingu rises, picks up his clapsticks and heads for the ceremonial ground. In his h

igh, keening voice, he sings. His brothers and cousins gather around him; the evening star shines; the funeral chants, shot through with pain and beauty, begin.

barbecue anxiety can be cured, writes Judy Adamson. Just ask a butcher.

Winter is over and about the same time as doonas and flannelette jammies go back in the cupboard, a warm- weather creature is emerging from hibern

the barbecue expert.

They're visible across Australia on most weekends, lounging near public or backyard barbecues, drink in hand. Rest assured, though, they all reckon they know how to barbecue meat. Trouble is, their

s often differ - which may be why the sausages regularly get burnt or the steaks are tough.

Even the meat kings - our local butchers - don't agree on everything about barbecuing. But at least they know more than your av

backyard expert.

Terry Wright, who has been dispensing wisdom for more than 40 years at Terry Wright's Gourmet Meats in Randwick, says a common mistake is to fill a barbecue with half a dozen steaks and masses of sausa

at once.

"If they've loaded the barbecue, they've taken the heat off the barbecue," he says, explaining that this will make the meat "stew" rather than keeping its juices in.

"It's vitally important ... Place one piec

on at a time, give it a minute and then place another piece on ... Don't fill the barbecue plate up [at once] and expect

to have a nice steak. Make sure your barbecue plate is searing hot at all times."

That's not qui

the view of Steve Paterson, the owner of McDonagh's Meat Boutique at Midway in Ryde. He believes the cooking surface can be too hot and therefore burn your meat. John O'Halloran, of Mountain Valley Meats in Cronulla, ag

preferring a "reasonable temperature" and slightly longer cooking time.

Steve Penny, whose family owns Penny's Quality Butchers in Mosman and Mona Vale, advises care with meat marinated in honey and soy as it "tends to

" when placed on a barbecue's hottest part.

Sausages are a barbecue essential, and while most butchers we spoke to prefer thicker sausages for the extra chomp and taste factor, O'Halloran warns that it's harder to stop

from burning because of the extra time they take to cook.

Wright suggests one way to avoid this is to blanch them first. Another option is to poach them in red wine: fill a pan with enough wine to cover the bottom thir

of the sausages and let them poach until it evaporates, by which time "the sausage is just starting to brown beautifully". Then you can bang them on the barbie. 

According to Sam Caminiti of Caminiti Butchery in Five D

the key is not so much the thickness of the sausage as "what goes inside".

"If you put good meat inside, it comes good," he says. "It's got to be fresh and good quality meat from the shoulder. That's much better than l

meat."

This brings us to the vexed question of steak choice. Most of our butchers plump for the New York steak as the best quality barbecue option, but also suggest rib-eye, boneless sirloin, T-bone and rump steak.

Ca

says the (aptly named) barbecue steak is good for those on a budget, while Paterson is a big fan of oyster blade steak.

"It's a cheaper cut, but flavoursome - it's sensational," he says. "It keeps moist, too, so

if yo

husband's drinking beer with friends out the back and burns it, you'll still be right. You don't want to give them a $40-a-kilo steak and have them burn the crap out of it so it tastes like a cardboard box."

Once your

steaks and other options are cooked, though, what should you put on them?

Not surprisingly, most of our butchers prefer their meat undressed, as such, but they do have some favourite sauces.

Paterson suggests a barbec

sauce called Big Rick's and recommends seasoning the barbecue plate before you cook the meat by cooking your onions first. Penny likes "a spicy plum barbecue sauce or a nice chutney" with sausages, and horseradish mixed

h sour cream on a steak, while at Caminiti family barbecues you'll be offered a dipping mix of oil, vinegar, garlic, salt, pepper and oregano.

One last tip: the all-important timing. Backyard barbecuers regularly make t

mistake, O'Halloran says, of putting on their steaks before the sausages.

That might be OK if you like a really well-done steak, he says, but if you want a good medium steak, "put your sausages on just a fraction befor

to make sure that they're completely done - and never, ever, prick them, which will "let all the juices out all over the joint".

Turn them once only.
